in the past years, the european union has been working towards developing regulations and guidelines to protect individuals' personal information. these initiatives are aimed at ensuring that people have control over their personal data and can limit its use by companies. as a result of these efforts, the general data protection regulation (gdpr) was passed in 2016, which provides eu citizens with a set of fundamental rights related to their personal data.

these rights include: 
- the right to be informed about how your data is being used and processed 
- the right to access your own personal information 
- the right to have your personal information corrected or deleted 
- the right to object to the processing of your personal data for specific purposes 
- the right to restrict processing of your personal information 
- the right to transfer your personal information in a usable format 

in addition, gdpr requires companies to obtain consent from individuals before collecting and using their personal data. companies are also obligated to ensure that they have appropriate security measures in place to protect the data and prevent any unauthorized access or use of it. 

overall, these regulations aim to give people more control over their personal information and ensure that it is protected against misuse.<|endoftext|>
